Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I glance at the overflowing laundry basket in the corner of our living room, the shirts and towels spilling out like a silent accusation. My husband had asked if I could fold them before my shift, and I promised I would. But now, standing at the edge of the pool in my red lifeguard suit, whistle around my neck, I spot a group of teenagers laughing and pushing each other dangerously close to the no-diving signs. My mind races—at home, I’m expected to keep things running smoothly, to share the load, to be a good partner. Here, I’m responsible for everyone’s safety, expected to be vigilant, to enforce the rules no matter what. I feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me, the guilt of the laundry left undone and the urgency of the risky behavior in front of me. My heart pounds as I wrestle with the demands of being both a reliable wife and a responsible lifeguard, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
